content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. Work has been so stressful, and I just can't seem to turn off my thoughts at night. I'm worried about losing my job and not being able to take care of my family, and it just feels overwhelming.

That sounds like a lot to be carrying right now. Stress at work and concerns about your family's well-being are heavy burdens, and it makes sense that they're affecting your sleep. It must be tough dealing with all of those thoughts at night. How have you been handling this so far?

Honestly, I haven’t been handling it well. I just lie in bed replaying everything in my mind, trying to figure out how to fix things at work or what I’ll do if I get fired. I’ve tried distractions like watching TV or scrolling on my phone, but that doesn’t seem to help either. I feel exhausted, but my brain just won’t shut off.

It's clear that you're doing your best to cope, even though it feels like nothing is helping right now. Replaying those concerns and searching for solutions must make it hard to find any rest. Feeling exhausted but unable to quiet your mind sounds really frustrating. When your brain won’t shut off, is there anything that calms you, even a little?

It's clear that you're doing your best to cope, even though it feels like nothing is helping right now. Replaying those concerns and searching for solutions must make it hard to find any rest. Feeling exhausted but unable to quiet your mind sounds really frustrating. When your brain won’t shut off, is there anything that calms you, even a little?

It’s good that you’ve noticed what doesn’t work and are still trying to find something that might help. Stress can make it hard to connect with anything soothing, and even small moments of calm might feel hard to find right now. Would it help to explore what typically brings you comfort, or ways you’ve managed stress in the past?

Honestly, not much has been helping. Sometimes I try deep breathing, or I’ll go check on my kids and remind myself why I’m doing all this, but even that doesn’t put my mind at ease for long. I just feel like there’s so much at stake, and I don’t know how to let go at night.

It sounds like you’re really trying to find moments of peace, even when it feels so difficult. The deep breathing and reminding yourself of your family show how much you care—and how hard you’re working to manage everything. It makes sense that letting go at night feels nearly impossible when the stakes feel so high. What do you think would need to change, even a little, to make it easier to relax?

It’s like I can’t stop thinking about all the risks and what might go wrong. Maybe if I felt more secure at work or had some kind of reassurance, it would help. But right now, I don’t even know where to start. It feels like everything’s resting on me, and I can’t afford to mess up.

It sounds exhausting to carry so much responsibility and feel like all of this depends on you. Worrying about security and wanting reassurance are very human responses when things feel uncertain. Not knowing where to start can make it harder to move forward. What feels the most important to focus on right now—your work situation, your sleep, or something else?

It’s hard when everything feels like it’s piling up and there’s no clear way forward. I think right now, I’d like to be able to focus on getting better sleep because I know I can’t function well without it, but the work stress is so tied into it. It’s hard to separate the two. I guess I just don’t know how to untangle it all.

It sounds like sleep feels like a priority for you, but the weight of work stress is making it hard to find a way forward. The connection between the two makes it so challenging to untangle, especially when it feels overwhelming. Taking even small steps toward improving your sleep or addressing the stress could help. What feels manageable to start with, even if it's just one small step?

It sounds like sleep feels like the starting point for you, but the work stress is constantly pulling at you, making it hard to fully disconnect. It’s okay to not have all the answers right now—it’s a lot to deal with. Maybe we can explore some small, practical steps together to help with your sleep first? What do you think?

That could be a great approach—to focus on small, practical steps toward better sleep, while keeping in mind how tied everything feels together right now. If you’d like, we can explore ideas together, or you could share things you’ve thought of that might help you relax before bed. Would you like to take that step right now?
That sounds like a good idea. I’m open to hearing any ideas you have, or we can figure something out together. I’m willing to try anything at this point to see if it helps.

Thank you for being open to exploring this. Before sharing some strategies, is there anything else tied to your sleep, stress, or current situation that you'd like to talk about first? It's important to go at your own pace.

It’s good to hear you’re open to trying something new. One option might be setting up a relaxing bedtime routine, like limiting phone use before bed, trying meditation or a sleep story, or even jotting down your worries in a notebook to get them off your mind. We can figure out what might work best for you together—what do you think might feel doable?

Those are thoughtful options to consider. Taking small, manageable steps, like creating a calming bedtime routine, could be helpful if it fits into your life right now. What stands out to you most from those ideas, or is there something you’d like to try adding to your evenings that feels more personal to you?

I think writing down my worries might help a little. I’ve never tried it before, but maybe if I get them out of my head, it’ll make it easier to feel less overwhelmed at night. I could probably start with that and see if it makes a difference.

That sounds like a meaningful step, especially since it gives you a way to release some of the tension and keep your worries from circling endlessly. Starting with writing them down might bring more clarity or even a sense of relief. How do you feel about trying this tonight or setting it up as part of a regular bedtime routine?
